Submodules¶

jaxl.gather_expert_data module¶

This script is the entrypoint for evaluating RL-trained policies. XXX: Try not to modify this.

jaxl.gather_expert_data.main(config: FlagValues)¶

Orchestrates the evaluation.

jaxl.learning_utils module¶

jaxl.learning_utils.get_learner(learner_config: SimpleNamespace, model_config: SimpleNamespace, optimizer_config: SimpleNamespace) → Learner¶

Gets a learner.

Parameters:

  • learner_config (SimpleNamespace) – the learner configuration

  • model_config (SimpleNamespace) – the model configuration

  • optimizer_config (SimpleNamespace) – the optimizer configuration

Returns:

a learner

Type:

Learner

jaxl.learning_utils.load_evaluation_components(run_path: str, buffer_size: int) → Tuple[Policy, Dict[str, Any], RunningMeanStd | bool, Env, ReplayBuffer, int]¶

Loads the latest checkpointed agent, the buffer, and the environment.

Parameters:

  • run_path (str) – the configuration file path to load the components from

  • buffer_size (int) – the buffer size

Returns:

the latest checkpointed agent, the buffer, and the environment

Return type:

Tuple[Policy, Dict[str, Any], Union[RunningMeanStd, bool], ReplayBuffer, Env, int,]

jaxl.learning_utils.train(learner: Learner, config: SimpleNamespace, hyperparameter_str: str, save_path: str | None = None)¶

Executes the training loop.

Parameters:

  • learner (Learner) – the learner

  • config (SimpleNamespace) – the experiment configuration

  • hyperparameter_str (str) – the hyperparameter setting in string format

  • save_path (str: (Default value = None)) – the directory to save the experiment progress

jaxl.plot_utils.set_size(width_pt, fraction=1, subplots=(1, 1), use_golden_ratio=True)¶

Reference: https://jwalton.info/Matplotlib-latex-PGF/ Set figure dimensions to sit nicely in our document.

Parameters:

  • width_pt (float) – Document width in points

  • fraction (float, optional) – Fraction of the width which you wish the figure to occupy

  • subplots (array-like, optional) – The number of rows and columns of subplots.

Returns:

fig_dim – Dimensions of figure in inches

Return type:

tuple

class jaxl.utils.RunningMeanStd(epsilon: float = 0.0001, shape: Sequence[int] = (), a_min: float = -5.0, a_max: float = 5.0)¶

Bases: object

This keeps track of the running mean and standard deviation. Modified from Baseline. Assumes shape to be (number of inputs, input_shape).
